Answer: Not really, no, it has nothing to say on that topic.What it says is, if you don’t know how television works, then you can’t tell moving images on a screen transmitted via (scientific explanation) from magic such as that used in say a crystal ball.The key here though isn’t simply that you don’t understand it, but that it must be “sufficiently advanced” relative to you. You probably have a vague idea how TV works, which means it doesn’t really seem like magic to you. But try that same TV on a native from a tribe deep in the Amazon or… well, actually, I don’t know why I’m trying to reinvent the wNot really, no, it has nothing to say on that topic.What it says is, if you don’t know how television works, then you can’t tell moving images on a screen transmitted via (scientific explanation) from magic such as that used in say a crystal ball.The key here though isn’t simply that you don’t understand it, but that it must be “sufficiently advanced” relative to you. You probably have a vague idea how TV works, which means it doesn’t really seem like magic to you. But try that same TV on a native from a tribe deep in the Amazon or… well, actually, I don’t know why I’m trying to reinvent the wheel here, go watch the wonderful film The Gods Must Be Crazy.

Answer: Even if you were shown a holographic TV that projects a 3D image directly in front of you, you wouldn't feel it was magic.But if say someone from another planet came along and demonstrated teleportation, that might appear pretty magical, although I think we would still just attribute it to superior science and technology.In fact it's hard to imagine something that could be done under repeatable circumstances that we would accept as magic. That isn't because our technology is so advanced, but that so much has been developed over the last 100 years that we see technology as having vast possibiliEven if you were shown a holographic TV that projects a 3D image directly in front of you, you wouldn't feel it was magic.But if say someone from another planet came along and demonstrated teleportation, that might appear pretty magical, although I think we would still just attribute it to superior science and technology.In fact it's hard to imagine something that could be done under repeatable circumstances that we would accept as magic. That isn't because our technology is so advanced, but that so much has been developed over the last 100 years that we see technology as having vast possibilities including things that can't yet be realised.
name: Shubham Bhatt
question: https://www.quora.com/Does-Arthur-C-Clarkes-third-law-Any-sufficiently-advanced-technology-is-indistinguishable-from-magic-bug-you-Does-it-mean-that-not-understanding-the-process-of-say-understanding-how-a-TV-is-impossible-for-someone-to

Answer: Clarke’s “law” isn’t a law. It’s a quip, an adage. It’s not an assertion of unassailable truth but a vague observation on human nature.It doesn’t bug me at all. There’s nothing disturbing or concerning about it.The sentence “Does it mean that not understanding the process of say understanding how a TV is impossible for someone to learn how to construct one“ seems to have lost its way at some point, but anyway: it’s not impossible to learn how to construct TV sets. In fact, people produce TV sets at a rather rapid pace.A TV set isn't magic. It’s also not at all easy to manufacture from scratch,Clarke’s “law” isn’t a law. It’s a quip, an adage. It’s not an assertion of unassailable truth but a vague observation on human nature.It doesn’t bug me at all. There’s nothing disturbing or concerning about it.The sentence “Does it mean that not understanding the process of say understanding how a TV is impossible for someone to learn how to construct one“ seems to have lost its way at some point, but anyway: it’s not impossible to learn how to construct TV sets. In fact, people produce TV sets at a rather rapid pace.A TV set isn't magic. It’s also not at all easy to manufacture from scratch, and if you did, it would be useless without a whole world of technology around it: electricity, broadcasting and cable stations, studios that produce content, and so on.So yes, if we’ve lost everything and wanted to produce a TV set from raw, natural materials, it would take a lot of effort and a lot of time. We’d need to make much simpler things first, and then more complicated things, a process of many layers. But there’s no magic involved, and nothing we can’t teach and learn.

Answer: Hardly, it is virtually a tautology with no real meaning.Consider the use of “sufficiently advanced”; what does it mean? It means advanced enough to be indistinguishable from magic.So the expanded version of the line is “Any technology that is so advanced that it seems magical will seem magical.”

But those are just stories.Now take a look at this, this is a 1.8 million year old tool, made by animals that were so close to us that it barely makes any difference. It’s called a hand axe, in this case an Acheulian hand axe.Acheulean HandaxeI couldn’t possibly make a tool like this, and it is already so advanced that I would likely never conceive of it in my own, just look at all those stone chips so perfectly formed, that INo. Seriously I enjoyed Arthur Clarke’s books, to a point. He was a good hard SciFi writer, who crossed over into pure fantasy. But those are just stories.Now take a look at this, this is a 1.8 million year old tool, made by animals that were so close to us that it barely makes any difference. It’s called a hand axe, in this case an Acheulian hand axe.Acheulean HandaxeI couldn’t possibly make a tool like this, and it is already so advanced that I would likely never conceive of it in my own, just look at all those stone chips so perfectly formed, that I don’t know and I can’t even imagine the actual process by which it was made and likely could not reproduce such a thing if I spent my whole life trying, but there it is. I don’t consider it magic. I consider it brilliant. Much like the natives in many lands who were suddenly confronted with modern technology, like chronometers (most valuable of all), and guns and metal tools certainly did not regard such things as magical, but instead knew damn well that they were simply better tools than those they already had, and already knew how to build.Any sufficiently advanced technology will

Answer: In 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we weIn 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we were required to corrupt product that had been shipped to China and it started a major debate about our fiduciary responsibility to the country or to the customer. The issue was that if you sell a security product that you know is corrupted, you are knowingly committing fraud and are liable. As the Product Manager at the time I asked the NSA if they would stand behind us (and me as I might be personally liable) in court if we were discovered. Of course the answer from the NSA was “Hell no.”We were on our own. We then entered into a long debate about how to detect Easter eggs and other corruption introduced into security products unknowingly through another vendor’s corrupted hardware. The issue was never resolved but it should be known that our security source code HAD to be provided to the NSA in order to get FIPS certification and they made certain changes to it.So to answer your question, USA military technology is advanced far beyond anyone’s knowledge to describe the extent.On the other hand, the Chinese probably know more about our technology than we do since they perpetrated the greatest security breach in history by compromising the RSA key technology used by almost everyone in the world. We only learned of it through the vigilance of Lockheed-Martin who discovered the breach accidentally. But for months the Chinese had the key to almost every computer in the world.

Answer: Well, before a hackathon, find out the language(s) that will be used in the Hackathon. Also, look at the problem statement (if any has been given already) or the idea that your friend has conceptualized. Also, if it is something like an "appathon", then discuss your idea thoroughly with your friend. Further, also discuss it's implementation.Once all the discussion is done, ask your friend to tell you where you can help. If he has invited you, there must be a reason for that, clarify this reason. And then strengthen your skills related to this reason.And remember to have fun! Hackathons are alWell, before a hackathon, find out the language(s) that will be used in the Hackathon. Also, if it is something like an "appathon", then discuss your idea thoroughly with your friend. Answer: You absolutely have to bring your own computer. If you get a computer provided to you, it's gonna suck, it's not going to have any of what you need on it, and you'll spend more time figuring out an unfamiliar setup than you will programming. Just… bring your own. Trust me.Other necessities learned of after attending way too many hackathons:You absolutely have to bring your own computer. If you get a computer provided to you, it's gonna suck, it's not going to have any of what you need on it, and you'll spend more time figuring out an unfamiliar setup than you will programming. Just… bring your own. Trust me.Other necessities learned of after attending way too many hackathons:And for the love of god, wear comfortable clothes.

Answer: Recently Paytm organised its first hackathon. Even it was our first hackthon. Before I begin with my experience I would like to share that we are enrolled in Bachelor of Technology course in computer science and are currently in theI have subscribed to Hackathon.com mailing list and get updates for hackathons happening near me. Through this I got to know Paytm was organising its first hackathon and the ticket was free of cost. The only eligibility beinRecently Paytm organised its first hackathon. Even it was our first hackthon. Before I begin with my experience I would like to share that we are enrolled in Bachelor of Technology course in computer science and are currently in theI have subscribed to Hackathon.com mailing list and get updates for hackathons happening near me. Through this I got to know Paytm was organising its first hackathon and the ticket was free of cost. The only eligibility being here was to propose a lucrative idea(that throws a great impact on Indians) and explain how you would use Paytm APIs with it.So I was ready with an idea and called 3 of my peers to come up as a team, who further contributed towards polishing the idea. No later, we gave our proposal and mailed the organiser personally elaborating the idea. The day later we got a mail from the organiser. He found our idea really interesting and asked for our applications. Soon we got theMy Team:The rightmost guy in this picture is me. The other guy is Prateek Arora and from the girls are Nikita Taneja and Nidhi Chhillar.As soon as we reached the Paytm’s office we were astonished by looking at the crowd there. We found ourselves as theWe took photographs, interacted with staff and no later, we were taken to our workspaces and were asked to settle ourselves. Caffeine stalls were set all over. Food and snacks were also arranged by the organisers itself. The thing began with some introductions and overview of their APIs. Some already started to code while some were taking part in whatever was happening on stage. We decided toAfter an hour or two,Apart from coding stuff, we met some smart peeps over there and discussed our ideas with them. Most of the teams were corporate ones. Some came to launch their startups with well-versed marketing strategies too. All in all, it was a great learning process interacting with such people.Some hours later, guys fromWe went back to our workspaces and resumed with the code stuff. Our work was totally based onAll we brought with us was some learning, some new experience, gained some knowledge from smart fellows, new skills and ofcourse not to forget the Hackathon Swag and our small-but-engouraging achievement:Here’s what we call Hackathon Swag!Just wanted to end with saying that,Needless to say, Hackathons can change your perspective towards coding, for good. Period.UPDATE: Got a few requests about what our idea was. We intended to build a peer teaching app, where anyone with a knack or skill could sign up as a teacher and can earn part-time at their own convenience. Any student who wishes to gain knowledge or guidance on a particular subject can get a teacher on per minute basis. (Charges would be as low as Rs 2/min). The app will look for all teachers nearby and will match their expertise that the student desires for. Could prove of great help during last moment studies.We are still working on the project. Still a lot of challenges are yet to be tackled.
